block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a winged preschooler who has sprouted wings, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a winged preschooler who has sprouted wings, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''EVERYTHING ABOUT CAMP (ALMOST),'' an hourlong revue with scenes by Michael Slade and songs (one of the standouts is called ''Bugs'') by numerous authors spoofing mess-hall menus, campfire ghost stories, swimming lessons and the exhortations of well-meaning moms and dads. Tada, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea. Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays at noon and 2 p.m.; Saturdays and Sunday, July 30, at 1 and 3 p.m. Tickets: $12; children, $6. Information: (212) 627-1732. Reservations advised.

''THE LAND OF SMILES,'' a musical with rod and hand puppets by the puppeteer-singer Susan Delery Whedon, with characters like Griti the Gremlin and Freddy the Frown. Saturdays and Sundays at noon and 1:30 p.m. Through Aug. 27. Papageno Puppet Theater, 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: (212) 874-3297.

''MINOTAUR,'' a hip-hop version of the Greek myth, presented by members of Urban Youth Theater. The story about a teenager who is half-human, half-bull, imprisoned in a labyrinth features rap, break dance and body rhythms. Henry Street Settlement's Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side. Thursdays through Saturdays at 7 p.m. Through July 29. Tickets: $5. Reservations: (212) 598-0400.

''THE UGLY DUCKLING,'' a musical version of the fairy tale by Debra Kaye, with lyrics by Brenda Bell. Presented by Literally Alive at the Hitchcock-Rockefeller Auditorium, Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue at 53rd Street. For ages 3 to 8. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., with art workshops at 1 p.m. Through Oct. 1. Tickets: $15; $5 workshop fee. Group rates for 20 and more. Reservations: (212) 866-5170.

''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' the L. Frank Baum story, featuring a country-western score for the Oz characters to sing and dance to, Sundays (through Aug. 20) at 1:30 and 3:30 p.m. Puppetworks at the Children's Aid Society, Greenwich Village Center Theater, 219 Sullivan Street, between Third and Bleecker Streets. For ages 3 and up. Admission: $8; $5 for children; $4.25 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations suggested: (718) 965-3391.
Events

''THE ADVENTURES OF ROCKY AND BULLWINKLE AND FRIENDS,'' a series of selections from works by the television animator Jay Ward, through Sept. 17 at the Museum of Television and Radio, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. Screenings are Tuesdays through Sundays at 12:15 p.m., with additional screenings Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. Through Sunday, the final 10 installments of Rocky and Bullwinkle's first adventure, featuring his archenemies Boris and Natasha. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

''BEATS OF THE TREES,'' a drumming demonstration and workshop with the percussionist Jean-Baptiste (Bonga), in which participants will create their own instruments and explore how nature inspires rhythms, tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m. For ages 6 and up. Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue. Information: (212) 860-1370.

''FRUITS OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL.'' Youngsters 6 to 12 can learn about all seven species of plants and fruits specified in the Bible, and pictured on the terrazzo floor of the Yeshiva University Museum's Children's Discovery Center, 15 West 16th Street, Sunday from 2:30 to 3:45 p.m. They can also create a stained-glass-style window decoration to take home. Free with museum admission: $6; $4 for children ages 5 to 12; under 4, free. Information: (212) 294-8330.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton, will be the place for New York City firefighters to demonstrate fire safety techniques tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. Highlights include a visit by the Fire Department mascot Hot Dog (someone dressed in a Dalmatian costume) who will show children how to extinguish burning clothes. Children will also learn how to escape from a simulated home fire, and, using long ropes, firefighters will slide down the side of the Intrepid to demonstrate their climbing skills. Events free on the pier. Information: (212) 957-7055.

KIDS' PERFORMING ARTS DAY on the main plaza at Chelsea Piers, Pier 62, 23rd Street and the Hudson River, tomorrow from noon to 4 p.m, featuring workshops and clinics in music, theater and dance. Performers include the Dazzling Mills Family, singers Ice Cream and Chocolate, the Irish band Morning Star, Barry Keatings' Starmite Puppets and the ice-skating show ''Summer Ice.'' Free. Information: (212) 336-6881.

NEW YORK FAMILY ARTS FESTIVAL, the second annual arts festival of multicultural performances and events, presented by the Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, at 120th Street, Morningside Heights. The festival runs daily through August. Tomorrow from 1 to 7 p.m. an Irish Village, including Circus Minimus (1 p.m.), Celtic storytelling (3 p.m.), Irish dance workshop (4 p.m.) and a performance by the Griffith Celtic Dance Company (7 p.m.). Sunday the theater becomes a Dominican Village with storytelling (2 p.m.), a mask-making workshop (3 p.m.), a documentary film (5 p.m.) and a performance of Dominican music and carnival (7 p.m.). Free. Information: (212) 870-6784.

STATEN ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Tomorrow at 3:30 p.m., an interactive Paper Puppet presentation of ''The Pied Piper of Hamelin,'' with puppets and noisemakers. Tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 4 p.m., ''Name That Bug'' workshop, in conjunction with the exhibition ''Bugs and Other Insects.'' Entry, $2 plus museum admission: $4; under 2 and members, free. Information: (718) 273-2060.

SOAP SCULPTURE WORKSHOP. A program for ages 5 to 12 to complement ''The Art of William Edmondson,'' an exhibition of limestone carvings, Sunday from 2 to 4 p.m. at the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street. Materials fee of $1; admission free. Reservations: (212) 595-9533.

''STORY CORNER: AFRICAN FRIENDS.'' Children will explore what it is like to visit Africa and make new friends through stories and photography, tomorrow at 4 p.m. with the educator Nichole Bridges, next to the exhibition ''Passages: Photographs in Africa by Carol Beckwith and Angela Fisher'' on the fifth floor of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

INVENTOR CENTER, at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, the Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street. Recent products from the next generation of inventors: a car with helicopter blades, a mechanical glove that contains school supplies and a Duck-a-Phone (it quacks instead of rings). Filled with 10 computer work stations, the center is a high-tech idea laboratory in which children use software developed by the museum to realize their wildest dreams during an hourlong workshop limited to children 6 and older accompanied by adults. Each day the center will offer six workshops; registration is required. The museum will provide everything needed, except, of course, imagination. Museum hours through Labor Day: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.Free with museum admission: $6; infants under 1, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.
Exhibitions

''REPTILES: REAL AND ROBOTIC,'' including an alligator snapping turtle 10 times life size and a Western diamondback rattlesnake 36 feet long, are part of the exhibition and related programs (through Sept. 17) at Science Playground at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Although those animals are robots, the real ones are no less impressive, including gila monsters, bearded dragons and blue-tongued skinks. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a 45-minute presentation with Robert Sousa from the New York Herpetological Society for $2. Hours in July and August: Mondays from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Tuesdays through Sundays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7.50; $5 for ages 4 to 17 and the elderly; free for ages children 3 and under. Information: (718) 699-0005.
Zoos

PRIMATE KEEPER WEEKEND ACTIVITITES at Prospect Park Zoo, 450 Flatbush Avenue, near Empire Boulevard, Prospect Heights, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4:30 p.m. Youngsters can hang out with the hamadryas baboons at 3 p.m. for a chat with zoo keepers about primates. Other activities include crafts and games and learning about primateslike the cotton-top tamarin monkey.. Zoo hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; weekends, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 399-7339.
